title: Real-Ear Aided Response and Audibility
chief_complaint: I am struggling to recognize speech on the telephone, in the classroom, and during group conversations.

problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Difficulty on telephone and in groups
problem_summary.functional_impact: Affects work as a tenured professor (teaching, advising students) and social interactions.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated; scheduled appointment himself to address communication struggles.

history.present_illness: Patient is a tenured professor responsible for teaching, research, and advising. He reports increasing difficulty hearing in daily environments.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to moderately severe hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with pure tone thresholds. Word recognition scores (WRS) are very poor bilaterally, disproportionate to the degree of hearing loss.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A) indicated by peaks near 0 daPa.

history.present_illness: Patient returned for fitting of bilateral Receiver-In-The-Canal (RIC) hearing aids.
history.prior_management: Hearing aids programmed initially using predicted RECD values.

tests.name: Real-Ear Measures (RECD Analysis)
tests.key_findings: Measured RECD values were significantly higher than predicted values, indicating the patient's ear canal volume is smaller than the 2cc coupler average. Using predicted values resulted in insufficient gain.

tests.name: Audibility Calculation (AI)
tests.key_findings: Initial programming (predicted RECD) provided suboptimal audibility. Using measured RECD would significantly improve access to speech cues.

overall_audiologic_summary: JN presents with a bilateral, symmetrical mild to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss with disproportionately poor word recognition scores (44-48%). Initial hearing aid fitting using predicted ear canal acoustics (RECD) resulted in under-amplification and patient disappointment. Investigation revealed his ear canals are smaller than average (higher measured RECD), requiring specific programming adjustments to achieve optimal audibility (AI 0.89 vs 0.74).
counseling_points: Your ear canals are smaller than the 'average' ear, which changes how sound behaves inside them.
Because we initially used an average prediction, your hearing aids were not giving you quite enough volume in the pitch ranges critical for speech.
By measuring your specific ear canal acoustics, we can adjust the hearing aids to provide the exact amount of sound you need.
This adjustment increases the audible speech cues available to you from 74% to 89%, which should help with your clarity on the phone and in class.
notes_for_actor: In the first visit, appear professional but concerned about your ability to teach and advise students effectively.
In the second visit (fitting), express clear disappointment. You expected these expensive devices to work immediately, but they don't seem to help much in the 'real world' yet.
Be skeptical until the audiologist explains *why* the first setting didn't work (the size of your ear canal).
